channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15593] Time limit of scanning should be offered by client
item.description: In RSRpcServices.scan, we will set a time limit equaling to Math.min(scannerLeaseTimeoutPeriod, rpcTimeout) / 2, and will response heartbeat message if we reach this limit. However, two timeout settings (hbase.client.scanner.timeout.period and hbase.rpc.timeout) are read from RS's configure, which may be different from client's. If client's setting is much less than server's, there may still be timeout at client side.
item.summary: Time limit of scanning should be offered by client

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: And a more general question: Will HBase RPC request contain a timeout from client? I don't find it but I'm not familiar with HBase RPC. If so we can use it; if not, there will be an optimization that we can drop rpc requests which are already timeout.
This optimization will be very useful when RS is slow and many requests are waiting.

We may have two options here:
1. Contains a deadline (unix timestamp+timeout) for each scan request, servers use this deadline. But users must use NTP to correct timestamps for each server.
2. Contains a timeout directly, we need not NTP here and will ignore the time from RPC client submit to RPC server receive.

Thanks for your reply. I use timeout in my patch and it fixes the bug of scanner time limit.

ScannerCallable.java

request =

    RequestConverter.buildScanRequest(scannerId, caching, false, nextCallSeq,

      this.scanMetrics != null, renew, callTimeout / 2);

Why callTimeout / 2?
Use the same logic as server side. It must be smaller than timeout because we should response before timeout. Half maybe an empirical value?
Use timeout setting of client directly in ScanRequest, keep /2 logic at server side only.

stack Any concern on the new patch? Thanks.

there will be an optimization that we can drop rpc requests which are already timeout.

Discussed with Duo Zhang, if we will add this optimization later, we'd better put timeout field into RequestHeader rather than ScanRequest because we will use this not only in scan rpc request.
Any ideas?

That sounds right. We should put priority into request header too to save an expense parse but that is for another issue.

Patch looks great.

On these:

267 private static final String MIN_CLIENT_REQUEST_TIMEOUT = "hbase.ipc.min.client.request.timeout";
268 private static final int DEFAULT_MIN_CLIENT_REQUEST_TIMEOUT = 20;

Timeout is in what unit? milliseconds?

Another issue is that the one thing we do not need in hbase is more ways to specify timeout (smile). We have timeouts and retries and many different levels making it very hard for operators to figure what to tweak to do stuff like fail fast. How does this new config. fit into the current scheme of things? How does it relate to current timeout and retry mechanisms? For example, could this supercede all other timeouts? Can we deprecate them? How does this relate to retries? At a minimum, we need some more doc on these new parameters (can copy/paste as release note for this feature).

Otherwise, patch looks great. It has potential to clean up a messy, long-running story around client timeout setting. Thanks Phil Yang
Oh, I see priority is already in the header... so, we should strip the finding of priority by parsing param... TODO.

The timeout's unit is ms and we need some comments/doc here.

This config is a protection like hbase.region.server.rpc.minimum.scan.time.limit.delta in RSRpcServices to prevent regarding this request as timeout immediately. It may not be necessary now because in scan heartbeat we have hbase.region.server.rpc.minimum.scan.time.limit.delta already, but it may be useful when we use it in other scsenes.

Thanks.

I find that PayloadCarryingRpcController extends TimeLimitedRpcController which has callTimeout. So we don't need change PayloadCarryingRpcController and can use TimeLimitedRpcController's callTimeout in RPC services.

but in branch-1 the test failed.

I think the issue is this:

RpcRetryingCaller.java

private int getRemainingTime(int callTimeout) {

    if (callTimeout <= 0) {

      return 0;

    } else {

      if (callTimeout == Integer.MAX_VALUE) return Integer.MAX_VALUE;

      int remainingTime = (int) (callTimeout -

          (EnvironmentEdgeManager.currentTime() - this.globalStartTime));

      if (remainingTime < MIN_RPC_TIMEOUT) {

        // If there is no time left, we're trying anyway. It's too late.

        // 0 means no timeout, and it's not the intent here. So we secure both cases by

        // resetting to the minimum.

        remainingTime = MIN_RPC_TIMEOUT;

      }

      return remainingTime;

    }

  }

In RpcRetryingCaller.callWithRetries of branch-1, we will change the rpc timeout if it is less than 2000 ms (introduced by HBASE-8764). My testcase is based on a 666ms timeout so it failed.
In master, the MIN_RPC_TIMEOUT has been changed to 1 by HBASE-13286. But it was only pushed to master...
So I think we can change this to 1 in this patches for branch-1.x directly in this issue, right?
Patch for branch-1

We have applied this patch to production cluster(0.98) simultaneously with porting all other features on scanning RPC chunking/heartbeat. Clients should be upgraded to the new version to support new protocol, but not all users done this work right now. So now we are still collecting information about scanning chunking/heartbeat.

For this issue, I think it is ok to commit, because it is not a big modification and I think it is a bugfix because users usually set their own hbase.client.scanner.timeout.period, and a small timeout will result in the heartbeat ineffective.

stack Yeah, I'm good with it in 1.3.

Skimmed the last patch, had a few questions as I go though..

requestHeaderBuilder.setTimeout(call.rpcTimeout > Integer.MAX_VALUE ?

This check looks weird?


/**

270	   * Minimum allowable timeout (in milliseconds) in rpc request's header. This

271	   * configuration exists to prevent the rpc service regarding this request as timeout immediately.

272	   */



....

if (header.hasTimeout()){

1938	        timeout = Math.max(minClientRequestTimeout, header.getTimeout());

1939	      }

Why do we need that? If that to prevent clients from accidentally or willfully setting ridiculously small timeout with high num retries and DDOS-ing cluster? If you're a client and want smaller latency, talk to cluster admit?

This check looks weird?

call.rpcTimeout is a Long and if it is greater than Integer.MAX_VALUE, (int)call.rpcTimeout will be negative.

The conf minClientRequestTimeout is like minimumScanTimeLimitDelta = rs.conf.getLong(REGION_SERVER_RPC_MINIMUM_SCAN_TIME_LIMIT_DELTA, DEFAULT_REGION_SERVER_RPC_MINIMUM_SCAN_TIME_LIMIT_DELTA) in RSRpcServices. The rpc timeout is in all requests' header, so I think we need a new conf here.

Thanks for clarification, makes sense. +1 for branch-1.3
